text: - [Navneet] Hi, I'm Navneet,
I'm a principal specialist at AWS
and I work with healthcare
and life sciences customers
on building data strategies
including modern data governance
and federated data ecosystems.
- Hi, I'm Subrat,
I'm a senior solutions architect at AWS

and I work with healthcare
and life sciences customers.
Today we are going to introduce you
to a new feature within Amazon DataZone
called Custom AWS Service Blueprint.

Prior to custom AWS Service
Blueprint feature release,

DataZone supported three
types of environments

out-of-the-box, Default
Data warehouse environment,
Default Data lake environment,
and Default SageMaker environment

targeting personas like data
scientists and analysts.
Environments in a data zone project
provide the infrastructure
that is tools, storage and IAM permissions
for the project members.
Before adopting Amazon DataZone,

customers have been
managing data pipelines
using their own customized IAM roles
for their data management operations,
such as storing data in Amazon S3,
performing AWS Glue ETL jobs,

Amazon EMR Studio for
data processing and so on.

Hence, customer wanted to
bring their own IAM roles
and resources to Amazon DataZone.
Custom AWS Service Blueprint feature
gives them a mechanism to specify
and use their own customized IAM role
to connect to their existing AWS resources
to perform data operations.

Customers can also configure
AWS Service Blueprint

to bring their own
resources such as databases,
as data sources and subscription targets

to enhance governance
across these assets as well.
With this release,
administrator can configure data sources

and subscription targets
in Amazon DataZone console
and not restrict it to do those actions
in the data portal.
Let's dive into an example

of a customer business use
case from life sciences

research domain where we
will showcase downloading
of files using Amazon S3.
Customers often create catalog
of their raw genomic sequence files
and secondary process files,
such as genomic variant files.
Downloading those files individually

would be a tedious and
time consuming process
for the researchers.
As you can see on the screen,
Julia, who is an administrator,
collaborates with her data engineers
to enable project members to access

and download their raw
genomic sequence files.
Marina is a data research analyst
who wants to download those raw genomic
sequence files from our project.
To address this need,

Julia can leverage the
Custom AWS Service Blueprint
based Amazon S3 environment
and configure action links,

which provides Marina the
familiar S3 browser interface
from AWS console with access
to specific S3 buckets and folders,

and more importantly,
using an AWS IAM role
provided by Julia.
- [Navneet] Now we will follow Julia
as she works with a data producer
to ingest raw genomic sequence files
as data assets in Amazon S3
and then navigate to DataZone portal
to ensure the data is properly cataloged.

She starts by checking
the Amazon S3 location

where data producer has
ingested the sequence files.
Julia logs into AWS console
and navigates to Amazon S3.
Julia inspects the Amazon S3 location
to verify that all the sequence files
are uploaded at a location
which is built for a specific study.

Julia then navigates
back to Amazon DataZone

where she opened a
portal which is prebuilt
to actually inspect if the sequence files
are cataloged within the DataZone portal.
Within the DataZone portal,

Julia navigates to
"Oncology Research" project

and verifies that there's
already a published asset
called "genomicsequencedocuments",

which is actually pointing
to the sequence files in S3.
Julia then logs back into Amazon DataZone
and then inspects the domain

that was pre-created
called "LifeSciences".
Julia then points to a blueprint,

which is called Custom
AWS Service Blueprint
and enables the blueprint.
Once the custom blueprint is enabled,
Julia has several options to configure,
including using pre-built console links,
integrations generating data sources,
and subscription target using custom roles
and configuring custom links.
Julia navigates to AWS Service Blueprint
and builds a new environment
and this new environment is called
"GenomicsStudyExplorer".
For a project,
Julia selects a pre-built project
called "Oncology research".

It is the same project
that she just inspected

where the sequence files were
cataloged for findability.
For the permissions role,
Julia brings a pre-created role called
"Oncology_researcher_role".
This specific role is enabled

to have read only access
for that specific bucket
and that specific location
that has all the sequence files.
We select the region
and then we create an environment.

Now at this point, an
environment is created
based on Custom AWS Service Blueprint,
which actually points to
one of the S3 location
and that's how we're gonna configure it.
So in this case, what we're gonna do

is we are gonna create
a customized AWS links

and we're gonna point
to a specific S3 bucket
and provide a location.

And in this one, we'll
browse to the same folder

And we're gonna choose that folder.
So once a folder is selected for

that specific environment
called "drug research",
we are gonna customize this

and I'm gonna call this
action as "Genomics Explorer"
and customize it.
So now at this point,

we have a Custom AWS
Service Blueprint enabler.
An environment is created called
"GenomicsStudyExplorer",
which is using a specific project
and a specific role that was pre-created,
and it's actually navigating
to a specific Amazon S3 location,

which consists of all the
genomics sequence files.

That's how Julia works
with the data producer

to ingest sequence files as
data assets in Amazon S3,
navigates to DataZone portal
to ensure the data is properly cataloged
and then custom environment is built so

that Marina can then
access Amazon S3 location
using custom environment link
with a Amazon DataZone project.
- [Subrat] Marina,
a data research analyst associated
with the oncology research project,
logs into the DataZone portal.
Within the DataZone portal,

Marina navigates to the
"Oncology research" project.

This project has genomic
sequence files cataloged
as custom assets,
which are essentially pointers
or references to the actual files stored
in an Amazon S3 location.
These files are part of a specific study

conducted within "Oncology
research" project.
The DataZone portal allows members
of the oncology research project
to add additional metadata
to these genomic sequence files.

This metadata can be used
to enhance discoverability
and accessibility of the files,
making it easier for researchers

to find and request access
to the relevant data.
To facilitate seamless access
to the Amazon S3 location containing the
genomic sequence file,
as you saw earlier, Julia has already done

the setup using Custom
AWS Service Blueprint.

Marina then navigates to
the "environments" tab

and clicks on the genomic
study explorer link.
This action launches
an Amazon S3 location containing
the genomic sequence files.

This integration between
the DataZone portal

and the AWS environment
allows researchers like Marina
to efficiently access
and work with the data they need
without having to navigate
to specific AWS console
or manage multiple access credentials.

- [Navneet] The combination
of the DataZone portal,
custom asset management

and the Custom AWS Service
Blueprint environment

enables researchers in the
Oncology research project

and exploration process,
fostering a more collaborative

Thank you.
